comments: Except for a(1) = 3 instead of 2, a(n) is the least prime obtained as a binomial transform of n numbers. E.g. a(5) = (1,5,10,10,5,1).(1,1,1,1,1,6)= 37. - _Amarnath Murthy_, Nov 26 2003a(n) is the smallest m for which m>(tau(m))^n, where tau(m) is the number of divisors of m. [_Vladimir Shevelev_, May 31 2010]
links: Jens Kruse Andersen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1000
mathematica: NextPrime[ n_Integer] := (k = n + 1; While[ !PrimeQ[k], k++ ]; k); Table[ NextPrime[2^n], {n, 0, 35} ]f[n_] := NextPrime[2^n]; Array[f, 30, 0] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Jun 05 2015 *)
crossrefs: See A203074 for another version. Cf. A014211, A054321.
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_.
